project.teaser: Wear and corrosion protection play a crucial role in the effort of European Manufacturing Industries to maximise both efficiency and productivity because they are inherently related to the lifetime of the components and their manufacturing cost. Thermal Spray technologies for...
project.objective: Wear and corrosion protection play a crucial role in the effort of European Manufacturing Industries to maximise both efficiency and productivity because they are inherently related to the lifetime of the components and their manufacturing cost. Thermal Spray technologies for the deposition of Hardmetals were developed for this reason, i.e., specifically to provide higher resistance to sliding and abrasive wear, coupled with good corrosion resistance. In this field innovation is based on experimental trial-and-error and operational feedback, because the equations that can model the coating performance have to consider the mechanical properties of the hard phase and those of the metal binder, their microstructure and interaction, and their evolution during the non-equilibrium Thermal Spray process. The final coating properties depend on all these factors and more, and they are too many for a physical modelling workflow to provide reliable results on a time scale that is compliant with industrial responses to fluctuating markets, supply chains and regulations. On the other hand, tools based on experimental data that rely only on final coating macro properties require extensive datasets to be reliable. This again conflicts with the response time required by industrial innovation. Moreover, innovation in coating technology is not just a matter of performance and costs: industrial companies have to consider multiple other factors such as the impact on workers, hidden regulatory costs, environmental protection costs, and also general public opinion. CoBRAIN offers a solution to this need, exploiting the integration of computational and experimental data through semantic interoperability, and developing an intelligent tool that will be able to propose novel materials from the class of High Entropy Hardmetals for direct deposition by HVOF, HVAF and CGS Thermal Spray, and capable to estimate their impact on the economy and the environment.
project.title: Integrated Computational-Experimental material Engineering of Thermal Spray coatings
project.keywords: Materials Modelling, Powder Technology, Material synthesis, Fluid Dynamics, Integrated Computational Materials Engineering, Metadata, Domain Ontology, Advance Characterisation, Thermal Spray

article.title: Intelligent tool accelerates discovery of high-performance hard metal coatings

result.title: Report on the Open Translation Environment and Tbox
result.description: EMMO based ontology modules in OWL2 DL (TBox) for the representation and documentation of the Thermal Spray domain and data and for the specific CoBRAIN application user cases.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - CoBRAIN (Integrated Computational-Experimental material Engineering of Thermal Spray coatings)
result.teaser: Protective coatings against wear and corrosion play a critical role in many industrial fields. However, extant technologies have considerable sustainability drawbacks. A prime example is electroplated Cr, a safe material whose deposition however involves highly toxic and...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

webItem.alternativeText: Figure 1. Layout of the approach of the CoBRAIN project and its current implementation status.
Figure 4. Example of phase composition modelling by CalPhaD, experimental verification and ML model.
Figure 3. Current status of the characterization workflow development.
Figure 5. Phase-field solidification model of a HEA droplet with experimental verification.
Figure 2. General layout of the powder and coating production flows.

result.title: Guidelines for Specimen realization on HVOF, CGS, HVAF
result.description: The report provides the practical guidelines for a standardized, repeatable production of specimens for the generation of the experimental dataset in WP4. It covers any necessary setup of the system, the realization of specialized tooling (if any is needed), and process parameters, including e.g. gas and powder flow rates, torch/substrate kinematics, and possible pre-processing steps such as grit-blasting, cleaning and pre-heating of the substrates.

result.title: Description of the Modelling workflow according with CWA17284
result.description: The modeling workflow adopting MODA principles and definitions of the CWA17284 and utilizing the several multiscale materials modeling frameworks of COBRAIN will be described. The necessary focus is provided on interoperability, integration of characterization and experimental activities in addition to the exploitation and interactions between physics-based and data-driven approaches. AI/ML/DL models will be adopted to work alongside and enrich the physics-based capabilities. Baseline for code and data repositories and hardware for interacting with the workflow will be provided.

result.title: Description of the Characterization workflow according with CWA17851
result.description: CHADA-based representation of the different techniques used in the project, together with their integration in a unique characterisation workflow, following CWA17815-Materials characterisation - Terminology, metadata and classification specifications.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
